qas.question: Who noted that 14th century monks bought books in shops?
What form of art had the most prestige in this era?
What were many pieces of secular art carved from in this period?
Along with Duccio, what Italian artist was a noted innovator in this period?

context: During this period the practice of manuscript illumination gradually passed from monasteries to lay workshops, so that according to <a0_0>Janetta Benton<a0_0/> "by 1300 most monks bought their books in shops", and the book of hours developed as a form of devotional book for lay-people. <a1_0>Metalwork<a1_0/> continued to be the most prestigious form of art, with Limoges enamel a popular and relatively affordable option for objects such as reliquaries and crosses. In Italy the innovations of <a4_0>Cimabue<a4_0/> and Duccio, followed by the Trecento master Giotto (d. <a2_0>1337<a2_0/>), greatly increased the sophistication and status of panel painting and fresco. Increasing prosperity during the 12th century resulted in greater production of secular art; many carved <a3_0>ivory<a3_0/> objects such as gaming-pieces, combs, and small religious figures have survived.
